channel.title: College courses
channel.description: Registration time is coming for the spring semester and I'm having a hard time deciding what programming language I should take. What programming classes have you taken and why did you pick that language?

item.title: College courses
item.dc:creator: @RSCShadow RSCShadow
item.description:
@RSCShadow wrote:

Rodgerwilco:

C++ is the way to go.

Read full topic

item.title: College courses
item.dc:creator: @3lv3n_snip3r 3lv3n snip3r
item.description:
@3lv3n_snip3r wrote:

At the college I’m at right now, you start with an Introduction to Programming class. The next elective you can take involving programming C#. But there’s also HTML/CSS, Java, JavaScript, C++, and there could be more, I just haven’t looked into it too far because I only started in the fall. That’s just the programming side of the I.T. major, there’s also a few courses on hacking and quite a bit on networking. The thing is with the school I’m at, is that the I.T. program is only 2 years, so only an associates degree. So, the classes I want to take are Java, JavaScript, and C++, because I’m already set for taking C#.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @ziplock ziplock
item.description:
@ziplock wrote:

Well I feel as if learning to “think like a programmer” would be the best thing to learn. So you’re not sitting in front of a computer spitting out hundreds of memorized lines of code.

item.dc:creator: @eyeownyew Eyeownyew
item.description:
@eyeownyew wrote:

Java and C++ are my choices, along with electrical engineering.

Both are platform-independent, very nice feature.
Electrical engineering because I like hardware a lot more than software.

item.title: College courses
item.dc:creator: @_s11 s1gma
item.description:
@_s11 wrote:

none. teach yourself the applicable/required languages (can be done in less time) and use the time saved/credits on a class that teaches material that’s tougher to pick up on your own (generally more theoretical stuff)

if you’re in the situation that you absolutely have to pick one (what fucking college would do that to u though lol), do some research and pick the biggest paradigm shift you can. say you’re used to exclusively Java, go with Haskell/ML/Lisp. if you’re acquainted with imperative/OO and functional, go with something like Prolog. it might be tough but it’s loveing worth it in every case to do something extreme

Read full topic

item.title: College courses
item.dc:creator: @Fire_capez Fire capez
item.description:
@Fire_capez wrote:

I’m not in college either but you didn’t specify what you had already studied and what you were particularly interested in. I would recommend learning languages with different paradigms (object-oriented: java, function: haskell or ml).

Read full topic
